results.question: How is the fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets determined?
results.markdown_table_response: The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets is determined by using valuation techniques. These valuation techniques maximise the use of observable market data where it is available and rely as little as possible on entity specific estimates. If all significant inputs required for evaluating the fair value of a financial instrument are observable, the instrument is included in level 2.
results.csv_string_response: FVOCI = FVPL + FVPL * (1 + 0.01 x OFA)
results.json_rows_response:
The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in an active market is determined by using valuation techniques. These valuation techniques maximise the use of observable market data where it is available and rely as little as possible on entity specific estimates. If all significant inputs required for evaluating the fair value of a financial instrument are observable, the instrument is included in level 2.
If one or more of the significant inputs are not based on observable market data, the instrument is included in level 3.

results.question: How does a non-employee director receive his/her restricted stock unit award or option grant?
gold_answer: on the date of his or her initial appointment to the Board of Directors equal to the pro-rated amount of the annual grant
results.markdown_table_response: The non-employee directors receive their restricted stock unit awards or option grants on the date of their initial appointment to the Board of Directors, which is the earlier to occur of the first annual meeting of stockholders (generally held at least one year after the date of the grant) or the next annual meeting of stockholders (generally held no later than the tenth anniversary of the date of the grant). Additionally, options automatically granted to a director are exercisable after the tenth anniversary after the date of the grant, and the option agreement generally provides that the recipient has no right to receive the grant until the date of termination of the recipient's services.
results.csv_string_response: For the purpose of computing his/her restricted stock unit award or option grant, the recipient must have completed at least one year of service on the board of directors and must have served for at least one year as a non-employee director before the grant date. The recipient must have received a non-employee director award in the amount of the grant, or a pro-rata amount of the grant, no later than the tenth anniversary of the date of grant. For example, the recipient of the restricted stock unit award of $200,000 will receive $50,000 per year for the first year of service and will receive $25,000 per year for each year of service thereafter. If the recipient does not receive a non-employee director award within ten years of the date of grant, the grant will expire, and no restricted stock unit award will be granted.

results.question: Why was the disallowance of the shorter deductibility period would not affect the annual effective tax rate but would accelerate the payment of cash to the taxing authority to an earlier period?
gold_answer: Because of the impact of deferred tax accounting
results.markdown_table_response: This is a great question that is not just about accounting. It is also about tax policy and risk. The short answer is that the tax law and the tax code provide for the deferral of tax until the tax liability is determined. In the case of a liability for which there is significant uncertainty, the deferred tax asset has no value. The decision to defer the tax liability for the liability is at the discretion of the taxing authority. The taxing authority may elect to defer the tax liability even if the liability is not fully deductible. In this case, the tax liability is treated as a liability that will give rise to a future tax deduction. The liability is not treated as a liability for which there is a corresponding tax deduction.

results.question: When is revenue recognized?
gold_answer: Revenue is recognized when, or as, performance obligations under terms of a contract are satisfied, which occurs when control of the promised service is transferred to a customer.
results.markdown_table_response:
Revenue is recognized when, or as, performance obligations under terms of a contract are satisfied, which occurs when control of the promised service is transferred to a customer. Revenue is measured as the amount of consideration the Company expects to receive in exchange for transferring services to a customer (“transaction price”). The Company will then recognize as revenue the amount of the transaction price that is allocated to the respective performance obligation when, or as, the performance obligation is satisfied. When determining the transaction price of the contract, an adjustment is made if payment from a customer occurs either significantly before or significantly after performance, resulting in a significant financing component. None of the Company’s licenses and collaboration agreements contained a significant financing component at either December 31, 2019 or 2018.
The Company’s existing license and collaboration agreements may contain a single performance obligation or may contain multiple performance obligations. BCE capital expenditures totaled $3,988  million for the year, up $17 million over 2018. This corresponded to a capital intensity ratio of 16.6%, down 0.3 pts compared to last year. Capital spending in the year reflected the following:
• Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital spending in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to last year, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• Lower capital expenditures at Bell Media of $6 million in 2019, compared to 2018, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018

results.question: What are the capital expenditures for Bell Media in 2018 and 2019?
results.markdown_table_response: Capital expenditures in 2019 were $3,988  million, down $17 million from 2018. Capital expenditures in 2018 were $4 million, down $10 million from 2017.
results.csv_string_response:
CAPITAL EXPENDITURES
BCE capital expenditures totaled $3,988  million for the year, up $17 million over 2018. This corresponded to a capital intensity ratio of 16.6%, down 0.3 pts compared to last year. Capital spending in the year reflected the following:
• Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital spending in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to last year, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• Lower capital expenditures at Bell Media of $6 million in 2019, compared to 2018, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018
